Award.AwardTitle: Physical Building Information Modeling for Solar Building Design and Simulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is aimed at advancing the field of solar building design and simulation through the introduction of physical Building Information Modeling (BIM) and the study of its applications in solar buildings. The project includes research on a novel physical BIM method for integrated solar building design and simulation, and the development and introduction of a new course using the physical BIM prototype tool for designing solar buildings. The major objectives are to: (1) research the new method integrated physical BIM for holistic building energy simulation; (2) build a prototype of the method for solar building and simulation integrating photovoltaic, passive solar thermal, and daylighting systems; (3) test the BIM simulation results using benchmark simulations; (4) evaluate the usability of the method in architecture design classrooms; and (5) provide guidelines for software developers to create new tools for solar building and whole building simulations.


Bruce K. Hamilton

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project Physical Building Information Modeling for Solar Building Design and Simulation (NSF Award #0967446) aims to investigate a new and integrated method of Building Information Modeling and performance simulation for sustainable building design.

Intellectual Merit

Building Information Modeling (BIM) is an emerging technology in the Architecture / Engineering / Construction (A/E/C) industry. It is a digital representation of the building process and products, containing a database of building objects, their properties, and their relationships. Building performance simulation can provide architects and engineers with important analyses about the performance of a designed building before it is being constructed, in order to assist in the design decision and optimization process.

The project has produced new computational methods and software prototypes for integrating BIM, thermal and daylighting simulations, building-integrated photovoltaics (BIPV) calculation, and building performance optimization (Figure 1 to 6). The research results demonstrate how to convert building information models into multi-domain physical simulation models through automated steps with high efficiency and accuracy, and how to enable BIM to become a common user interface for architectural design and performance simulation. The mapping from BIM to physically-based simulation is proven to be a successful strategy for interoperability between architectural models and thermal and daylighting models. The research has advanced BIM, building simulation, and design optimization technologies and enhanced the interoperability among relevant software applications.

The research findings are disseminated through publications (see References). Software prototypes (Jeong et al. 2015; Kota et al. 2014; and Yan et al. 2013) and an open source program (Rahmani Asl et al. 2015b) are produced based on the project.

Broader Impact

The research outcomes will assist in the architectural design process for both new building construction and existing building retrofit in order to achieve sustainable buildings with more efficient energy use and less environmental impact. The project has been presented in Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC)-hosted New Energy - New City Forum for Developing Low-Carbon Towns During Economic Transition, Tianjin, China in 2012, as well as seminars or symposiums at Texas A&M University, Tianjin University, Tsinghua University, Stanford University, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. The project provided extensive research experience for undergraduate students and Ph.D. students at Texas A&M University. Based on the research project, Ph.D. students have completed their dissertations in related fields of study, and started to work in industry and academia.
